title: Castellón (Corts Valencianes constituency)
text:
Castellón () is one of the three constituencies () represented in the <a href="Corts%20Valencianes">Corts Valencianes</a>, the regional legislature of the <a href="Valencian%20Community">Valencian Community</a>. The constituency currently elects 24 <a href="Deputy%20%28legislator%29">deputies</a>. Its boundaries correspond to those of the Spanish <a href="province%20of%20Castell%C3%B3n">province of Castellón</a>. The <a href="electoral%20system">electoral system</a> uses the <a href="D%27Hondt%20method">D'Hondt method</a> and a <a href="Closed%20list">closed-list</a> <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a>, with a minimum threshold of five percent regionally.
Electoral system.
The constituency was created as per the <a href="Statute%20of%20Autonomy">Statute of Autonomy of the Valencian Community of 1982</a> and was first contested in the <a href="1983%20Valencian%20regional%20election">1983 regional election</a>. The Statute provided for the three <a href="Provinces%20of%20Spain">provinces</a> in the <a href="Valencian%20Community">Valencian Community</a>—<a href="Province%20of%20Alicante">Alicante</a>, <a href="Province%20of%20Castell%C3%B3n">Castellón</a> and <a href="Province%20of%20Valencia">Valencia</a>—to be established as multi-member districts in the <a href="Corts%20Valencianes">Corts Valencianes</a>, with this regulation being maintained under the 1987 regional electoral law. Each constituency is entitled to an initial minimum of 20 seats, with the remaining 39—29 until 2007—being distributed in proportion to their populations (provided that the seat-to-population ratio in any given province did not exceed three times that of any other). The exception was the 1983 election, when each constituency was allocated a fixed number of seats: 29 for Alicante, 25 for Castellón and 35 for Valencia.
Voting is on the basis of <a href="universal%20suffrage">universal suffrage</a>, which comprises all nationals over eighteen, registered in the Valencian Community and in full enjoyment of their political rights. Amendments to the electoral law in 2011 required for <a href="Spanish%20diaspora">Valencians abroad</a> to <a href="Voter%20registration">apply for voting</a> before being permitted to vote, a system known as "begged" or expat vote (). Seats are elected using the <a href="D%27Hondt%20method">D'Hondt method</a> and a <a href="closed%20list">closed list</a> <a href="proportional%20representation">proportional representation</a>, with a <a href="election%20threshold">threshold</a> of five percent of valid votes—which includes blank ballots—being applied regionally. Parties not reaching the threshold are not taken into consideration for seat distribution.
The electoral law allows for <a href="Political%20party">parties</a> and <a href="Political%20alliance">federations</a> registered in the <a href="Ministry%20of%20the%20Interior%20%28Spain%29">interior ministry</a>, <a href="Electoral%20alliance">coalitions</a> and <a href="Grouping%20of%20electors%20%28Spain%29">groupings of electors</a> to present lists of candidates. Parties and federations intending to form a coalition ahead of an election are required to inform the relevant Electoral Commission within ten days of the election call—fifteen before 1985—whereas groupings of electors need to secure the signature of at least one percent of the electorate in the constituencies for which they seek election—one-thousandth of the electorate, with a compulsory minimum of 500 signatures, until 1985—disallowing electors from signing for more than one list of candidates.
